content.description: Start on the Barnacle face below the X formed by the inverted V-shaped overhang and incipient cracks.
content.protection: TR: trees on top may need extra long anchors.
content.location: Jungle Clifs area of Carderock, MD   Right of "Elsie's".   On the Barnacle face

content.description: Start same as The Dream Direct.   Use a right heel hook above the notch, then brings hands up high on the face.
content.location: Start same as The Dream Direct.

content.description: Start same as the Death Nerve.   Climb up the wedge shaped flake.     If only the outside face of the wedge is used, its a 5.11
content.location: Jungle cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start same as the Death Nerve.

content.description: Start at the crack to the right of Upper Wall Crack.   #1. Often used as an easy solo route to get up and down this area.
content.location: Start at the crack to the right of Upper Wall Crack.

content.description: Start on the face above and right of Elsie's and above Barnacle Face.   #1. Often soloed, this can be done as a face climb or a layback. There are also face climbs to the right of the crack (5.8,5.10)
content.location: Start on the face above and right of Elsie's and above Barnacle Face.

content.description: Start same as The Dream.   Traverse to the edge with the hands, using the far right face for the feet. Hook feet around flake and layback.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start same as The Dream

content.description: Taken outside, near the grassy banks of a small river, on a glorious spring day, with plenty of butter and raspberry jam, few things in life are nicer than tea and crumpets. Congruently, there are few boulder problems on the Carderock schist that can compare to the delight that is known as Tea and Scrumpet. Yet, what  you may ask  is a scrumpet?  The Oxford English Dictionary defines it as "an elegantly awkward rock climbing move executed with one's genetalia an uncomfortably short distance from the rock."
content.protection: A bouldering mat placed near the arete saves the butt from damage, but is considered by many to be "unsporting."
content.location: This route traverses (left to right) from the front side of X-face, past Buckets of Blood Arete and onto the back wall with one important rule: you are not allowed to use any holds on or above the one inch roof on the Impossible Face (the face just left of Buckets of Blood Arete, shown in the center of the beta photo). The crux is the "scrump" move: getting both hands established on the arete. Kicking a foot across to the back wall is a harsh test of groin flexibility and may require substantial pre-game stretching.

content.description: Start at a rib 8 feet left of Ronnie's Leap, between Swayback Layback and Shipley's.   Follow rib. Use a combination of knobs as well as small right and left laybacks.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start at a rib 8 feet left of Ronnie's Leap, between Swayback Layback and Shipley's.

content.description: Climb straight up the center of the face to the left of Elsie's Arete and right of Copy Cat.

Layback & face climb up the right facing corner. 

  Pretty fun.
content.location: The rib 15' left of Ronnie's Leap and 6' right of Marian's Chimney.

content.description: Well, it's not really a 5.7, but that's part of the charm of Carderock, isn't it?  Work the semi-polished corner with a mixture of stemming, face-holding, and jamming.  The rock is bullet hard and clean, like most of Carderock. Pretty cool route that is unexpectedly technical and demanding for the grade.
content.protection: TR, though I think it would take gear reasonably well for the solid leader.
content.location: Right of The Dream roof on the Jungle Cliff (left side of Carderock).  Look for a prominent, right facing corner with an easy start and a gentle overhang for most of the second half.

content.protection: Top Rope, and after top roping, 3rd class. Would be a good ground up with mats, but crux is the top.
content.location: Overhanging edge right of Beginners crack (12m)

climbs.name: Shonard's Lunacy
climbs.fa: Bob the Aid Man. SDS Greg Collins

content.location: Down in the normal descent gully, west side, below the rim.

content.description: Climb the face straight up past the big crystal between Swayback Layback and Ronnie's Leap.  The holds for Ronnie's Leap are off route.
content.location: On Jungle Cliffs in the 'Beginner's Crack' Alcove. It is the face between Swayback Layback and Ronnie's Leap.

content.description:
Named after the eponymous dog of a neighbour of Jan Conn. Stories differ, but apparently the pooch saw a rabbit or squirrel below and charged off the cliff, landing dazed but unhurt at the bottom. 

  Another sort of eliminate. Deep in the right facing corner of the beginner's area, climb without using crack holds.
content.location: In the beginner's area of Jungle Cliffs, the deepest part of the right facing corner.

content.description: Climb the first 15 feet of large blocks with easy feet and hands. Stand on the second block and stare down the crux move reaching for high jugs or by fighting your way through small quartz pinches and crimps to an easy slab finish.
content.protection: Easy toprope tree anchor with two big trees above the climb. Can easily set up for The Rack Direct (5.11b) and Sterling's Crack (5.7) on same toprope.
content.location: Just right of Jane's Face near the prominent roof.

content.description: Start at the bottom outside corner to the left of Sterling's Crack.   #1. Using an undercling, move up to right edge and quartz nubbins on the left face; then work the feet high enough to reach better handholds. Pull the overhang. Keeping balance, continue  up the arete to the top.
content.location: Start at the bottom outside corner to the left of Sterling's Crack.

content.description: Start on the first boulder at the beginning of the cliff, approximately 50 feet left of Jan's Face.   Climb the overhang.   A traverse can be started here which goes all the way to Jan's face: stay only on the rock, especially in the Chockstone Chimney and around the tree
content.location: Jungle cliffs area.   Start on the first boulder at the beginning of the cliff, approximately 50 feet left of Jan's Face.

content.description: Start at the left end of Beginner's Face at the very edge of the rock.   #1. Climb face diagonally left. ending between two blocks.
content.location: Start at the left end of Beginner's Face at the very edge of the rock.

content.description: Often called just 'Meenehans' and is done as a right layback with the feet close to the edge. Although it may seem easier to use left handholds on the face about 8 inches from the edge, these are off route and often lead to an off balance position. This climb can be done one-handed.   A 5.10 finish requiring a layback on the upper block.
content.location: Start same as Meenehan's Staircase

content.description: Start: Base of a wide chimney formed by the left side of the Barnacle face.   Climb the chimney.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start: Base of a wide chimney formed by the left side of the Barnacle face.

content.description: Start at the base of a wide crack in Jan's Face.   Follow chimney to top.
content.location: Start at the base of a wide crack in Jan's Face.

content.description: Finding the right way is the difficult part here. For the path of least resistance, use both the face and the arete.  Fun moves on great rock.
content.location: Just like the name says: find Jan's Face, and climb the left edge.

content.description: Start at the right corner of the chimney and up to a small overhang   Go right around overhang and then up.
content.protection: TR: Trees on top. Bring long anchor materials.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   The face between Chockstone Chimney and Margie's Chimney known as Jan's Face.   Begin at the right edge of the Chockstone Chimney.

content.description: The climb can run anywhere up the face of the rock.  The quartz knobs are plentiful, but very slick and difficult to hold or stick a foot on.
content.protection: Natural anchors at the top.  Several trees and flakes are available.  You'll need 40-50 ft of fixed rope and 20-30 ft webbing for anchors.
content.location: Follow the Billy goat trail to the right and turn left at a small bridge (the approach trail is obvious).  Making the left puts you at the base of the rock.  Jane's Face is immediately after a chimney - it's not very far past the bridge/turn.

content.description: Start on an easy sloping face directly below crack.  About half way up you top out on this face and step across to the crack.  Use the crack and the holds on the face to go the rest of the way up.
content.protection: Top rope.  Make sure you bring plenty of webbing to set up the top rope.
content.location: It's in the Jungle Cliffs area on the far left side (facing the rock).  It's just to the left of Herbie's Horror and Jan's Face.

content.description: Start on the right facing  side of the Barnacle Face block.   Starting at the bottom right edge use fingertip holds to get to the quartz knobs. Proceed up. Variations can be done on the left edge (5.9) or in the center (5.10+).
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start on the right facing  side of the Barnacle Face block.

content.description: A nice climb and a good warmup and progression from Jam Crack.  It goes basically straight up left of Herbie's Horror from the top of the two detached flakes.  Decent holds and two small bulges to get past.
content.location: Between Jam Crack and Herbie's Horror on top of the two detached flakes at the base of the wall.

content.description: Start to the right of the Jam Crack slab but before you get into the chimney on the right.  Just to the right of the detached flake.  The holds are small and crimpy and good footwork is in order.  It gets a little thinner at the very top.
content.protection: Top rope.  Lots of webbing required as usual
content.location: Between Jam Crack and Chockstone Chimney.  Basically just left of the chimney area after Jan's Face in the Jungle Cliff area.

content.description: Stay between the left two of three incipient cracks.There are some nice big holds out left, but don't touch them; they are not on the route. Start with a committing and delicate layback, then climb thin holds to the top. The crux is about 2/3 of the way up.
content.protection: There is a large boulder and an arched tree root that can be use for the anchor. Do not use the fallen tree that overhangs the top of the route.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs, proceed up river from the main descent. It's about 3/4 of way to the end of the Jungle Cliff formation. Proceed a little further up river to a ramp that gains access to the top of the formation for anchor setup.

content.description: Start same as the Vulgarian Wedge.   Chimney up the rock between the Vulgarian Wedge and The Rack on the right.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start same as the Vulgarian Wedge

climbs.name: Evan's Bolt Ladder
climbs.fa: FA: Tom Evans (1969)  FFA: Chris Sharma (2007) while doing an interview for NPR

content.description: Start at the face just right of Sterling's Crack.   Climb straight up through downward flakes.
content.location: The Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start at the face just right of Sterling's Crack.

content.description: This is a test peace to see if you have foot work and balance, Its sidewise so your mid must be centered. This is rated 5.7 and strikes fear in the heart of leaders who think 5.7 is easy.
content.protection: Top rope off tree and block.
content.location: On the far southern end of Jungle Cliff on a groved steep left leaning face.

content.protection: Top rope. Deciduous trees provide the anchor. Maybe padding for the anchor rope. Nice angle for micro-traxioning, but low crux. Free soloed on routine by the late Peter Absolon. Even free soloed by Brr Matt Lavender. (On my circuits I found it sketchy-er than the Sloth, but not as hard as the Dream (direct in MP))
content.location: Left of the X on Barnacle face and right of Stearlings Crack is a steep, for Carderock, prow.

content.description: Begin on flaky holds on the right side of a low overhang and arete. Follow arete to top.
content.location: Arete just right of sweethog

content.description: The best line on Jane's Face, this tricky slab route features a couple of awesome mantle moves.  The holds you mantel on are deeply in-cut crimps, so you can pull them down to your ankles.     Most of the holds are reasonably good, but they often face the wrong direction, or require careful sequencing, very high steps, etc.  You'll probably find the crux to be at two-thirds height, where these features are amplified a bit.   A fun problem that can easily be tried from an anchor on The Flake, or Jane's Face.
content.location: Right of The Flake on Jane's Face.  Climb between the two thin seams, and head for the blankest looking faces.

content.description:
From AFALCON GUIDE by Eric J. Horst:    "Climb the grooved wall right of Elsie's Nose. The farther left you start, the harder the climbing." 

  Not to be confused with Elsie's Other, this climb varies from 5.6 to 5.8 depending on where you start (as indicated in the guide book).
content.protection: Trees at the top for TR.

content.description: Start on a large talus block at the base, and work up to the left side of the overhang.  Commit to the crimps, and traverse out to a jug or two.  Make your way over the lip (crux), and finish on 5.easy slab.     A fun boulder problem with an easy finish.  Make sure to warm up the fingers before you do it; the crimps are a little strenuous, and come out of nowhere, obviously.
content.location: The Dream is located on the left side of the crag (Jungle Cliff).  The easiest way to recognize it is by looking for the largest roof.

content.description: The direct version of The Dream is significantly harder.  12- might be a little stiff, but maybe my beta was bad.     Instead of cheating your way through the roof by starting on the left and traversing, attack the roof head on.  What looks like a burly reach is actually a technical endeavor.  Use a combination of knee bars, powerful underclings (find the crimps!), bicycles, and brawn to make your way to the relatively easy moves of The Dream.
content.location: Same roof as The Dream, only get right under it and go.

content.description: Kind of an eliminate.  Climb up using only the face, once above the diamond, head left for the top.
content.protection: You can slot some gear behind the flake or into the huge crack- but lets not kid ourselves, we'll just top rope it.
content.location: The face between the beginners crack and the flake to the left of it.

content.description: Start from a block right of The Dream roof.   Climb the right side of The Dream block using a flake to a long reach; a lunge move.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderrock, MD.   Start from a block right of The Dream roof.

content.description: Climb the right side of Jane's Face without using the wide crack.
content.location: Begin to right of a large tree and wide crack on the right side of Jane's Face.

climbs.name: Chris' Cruz
climbs.fa: Chris Sharma (2007) while being interviewed by NPR

content.description: Start in Chockstone Chimney, opposite Herbie's Horror.   Starting on the outer most edge of the chockstone chimney, where the left facing side meets Jan's Face, climb the wall nearest the edge and then up.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area.   Start in Chockstone Chimney, opposite Herbie's Horror.

content.description: Start at the base of the large chimney left of Jan's face.   Climb chimney using chimney technique and not the obvious easy corner.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area.   Start at the base of the large chimney left of Jan's face.

content.description: Straight up on knobs till you hit a big horizontal, then easy ground to the top out.
content.protection: One blue cam. But don't bother.
content.location: 10' left of beginner's crack

content.description: Perhaps the best steep climb at Carderock, the glorious overhanging arete on the back side of the X-face beckons the passing climber with its siren song of incut crimps on the right and heel-hooks on the left. An optional sit-start increases the difficulty and makes the top moves quite strenuous.
content.protection: The large block at the top of X-face can be used for a toprope anchor.  The climb is sometimes done as a highball boulder problem, but it should be noted that the quartz crystals offer much less friction than you might prefer at that height.
content.location: This climb is about 50 feet left of beginners crack and just a bit left of the dark, scary chimney.

content.description: This is the overhang with nasty little crimps at about head height. Stay off the Arete for the V10, and there is evidence of a butt-start for super points.
content.protection: Pad, some bat-hooks, and a positive attitude.
content.location: Obvious overhang lookers right of 'Buckets' Arete.

content.description: Climb the face to the right of Beginner's Crack.
content.protection: Toprope with 60 feet of static line, or lead (carefully, the pro isn't as good as you'd think.)

content.description: Though a bit slippery at the bottom due to thousands of climber's soles, this large crack in the Beginner's alcove is a great first climb.
content.protection:
Top Rope 

  Trad: Stances are great, and the gear is there if you get inventive (vertical placements, in crack placements, deep cams).
content.location: The Beginner's Area of Jungle Cliff is a large alcove between a huge tree and a large boulder in the ground slightly upstream from the descent.  Beginner's Crack is the large fissure in the center of this alcove.

content.description: Climb the large block leaning against the cliffs left of Beginner's Crack and wall.
content.location: Jungle Cliffs area of Carderock, MD.   Start: The large block leaning against the cliffs

content.description: Shaded by deciduous forest, Jungle Cliffs contains Carderock's most interesting rock. From the knobs of Herbie's Horror and the smooth bed of Jan's Face, on the upstream side to the roof of the Dream, steep prow of Elisie's Nose to the heavily visited Impossible and Beginner's Crack. The Sloth and Shonnard’s add steepness to the downstream side. Jungle Cliff contains routes from Overhanging Block to Shonnard’s Lunacy. Climbers Left side.
